justification: The article notes that "eye-movements closely reflected the behavioural relevance of each dimension" and that hypothesis-dependent sampling has been "identified through study of human eye-movements," indicating that eye-tracking data are used to measure selective attention during categorization tasks.

It states that "the initial difficulty of each task (as measured by the proportion of choice errors)" is a key outcome, showing that researchers quantify categorization performance via accuracy/error rates.
